Confidence intervals for raw residuals

Source: vignettes/ci_residuals.Rmd
ci_residuals.Rmd

Checking the normality and equal variance of standardized residuals is one of the most common routines when fitting linear models and, although some statisticians argue they are the less important assumptions to consider unless you focus on prediction, easily available software prompts anyone to either display all kinds of graphical inspections and null hypothesis tests.

Consider fitting the model ğ²=ğ—ğ›ƒ+ğ›œ\mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\beta} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon} to nn observations with pâˆ’1p-1 predictors. Asumming the error terms follow a multivariate normal distribution with mean vector ğŸ\mathbf{0} and covariance matrix Ïƒ2ğˆ\sigma^2 \mathbf{I}, we already know the covariance matrix of the residual vector ğ\mathbf{e} is Ïƒ2(ğˆâˆ’ğ‡)\sigma^2(\mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H}), where ğ‡\mathbf{H} is the influence matrix. If Ïƒ2\sigma^2 was known, confidence intervals could then be constructed because ğ\mathbf{e} would also follows a multivariate normal distribution. Nonetheless, this situation is utopian because we actually need to estimate the error variance. In this case, we may think that the ith studentized residual, ri=eiÏƒÌ‚1âˆ’hiir_i = \frac{e_i}{\widehat\sigma \sqrt{1 - h_{ii}}}, follows a t-distribution with nâˆ’pâˆ’1n-p-1 degrees of freedom but eie_i and ÏƒÌ‚\widehat{\sigma} are not independent. At this point, we may appeal to asimptotic approximations to simply use the t-distribution or compute the externally studentized residuals, which employ the error variance estimate that excludes the ith case. If we however want to to use the whole data, Ellenberg (1973) derived the joint distribution of a kind of standardized residuals. We will follow his derivation to get instead the joint density of the internally studentized residuals and will supply R code to plot confidence intervals for raw residuals. Because the improvement over the externally studentized residuals may not be huge, this derivation should be taken as a matter of curiosity rather than of practical value.

Let ğŒ=ğˆâˆ’ğ‡\mathbf{M} = \mathbf{I} - \mathbf{H} so that ğ=ğŒğ›œ\mathbf{e} = \mathbf{M} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}. Consider a kk-subset of residuals. The sum of squared residuals obtained by removing that subset from the regression is Sk2=S2âˆ’ğkâŠ¤ğŒkÃ—kâˆ’1ğk, S_k^2 = S^2 - \mathbf{e}_k^\top \mathbf{M}_{k\times k}^{-1} \mathbf{e}_k, where S2S^2 is the sum of squared residuals from the model fitted to the full data, ğk\mathbf{e}_k is the vector containing the subset of kk residuals and ğŒkÃ—k\mathbf{M}_{k \times k} is the corresponding partition matrix of ğŒ\mathbf{M}. We can rewrite it as Sk2=ğ›œâŠ¤ğŒğ›œâˆ’ğ›œâŠ¤(ğŒğŒ*ğŒ)ğ›œ=ğ›œâŠ¤(ğŒâˆ’ğŒğŒ*ğŒ)ğ›œ, \begin{aligned} S_k^2 &= \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^\top \mathbf{M} \boldsymbol{\epsilon} - \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^\top (\mathbf{MM^*M}) \boldsymbol{\epsilon} \\ &= \boldsymbol{\epsilon}^\top (\mathbf{M} - \mathbf{MM^*M}) \boldsymbol{\epsilon}, \end{aligned} where ğŒ*\mathbf{M^*} is a nÃ—nn \times n matrix with all the entries not related to the kk-subset set to zero. This is a quadratic form where ğŒ\mathbf{M} is idempotent and the rank of (ğŒâˆ’ğŒğŒ*ğŒ)(\mathbf{M} - \mathbf{MM^*M}) is nâˆ’pâˆ’kn-p-k, so Sk2Ïƒ2âˆ¼Ï‡2(nâˆ’pâˆ’k). \frac{S_k^2}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2 \Big(n-p-k \Big).

ğk\mathbf{e}_k is independent of Sk2S_k^2 so their joint probability density is $$ f(\mathbf{e}_k, S_k^2) = {\sf MVN} \Big(\mathbf{e}_k; \ \mathbf{0}, \sigma^2 \boldsymbol{\Sigma} \Big) \ \chi^2 \Big(S_k^2/\sigma^2; \ n-p-k \Big) / \sigma^2, $$ where ğšº=Ïƒ2ğŒkÃ—k\boldsymbol{\Sigma} = \sigma^2 \mathbf{M}_{k \times k}. Letâ€™s just focus on the residual ii from now on. Considering ÏƒÌ‚=S2/(nâˆ’k)\widehat{\sigma} = \sqrt{S^2 / (n-k)}, we apply a change of variables,

ri=eiÏƒÌ‚miiÏƒÌ‚2=Si2+ÏƒÌ‚2ri2(nâˆ’p), \begin{aligned} r_i &= \frac{e_i}{\widehat{\sigma} \sqrt{m_{ii}}} \\ \widehat{\sigma}^2 &= \frac{S_i^2 + \widehat{\sigma}^2 r_i^2}{(n-p)} \end{aligned},

Notice that by standardazing the residuals we ensure that Ïƒ2=1\sigma^2 = 1. The joint probability density now looks like f(ei,Si2)=ğ’©(riÏƒÌ‚mii;0,mii)Ï‡2(ÏƒÌ‚2(nâˆ’pâˆ’ri2);nâˆ’pâˆ’1). f(e_i, S_i^2) = \mathcal{N} \Big(r_i \widehat{\sigma} \sqrt{m_{ii}}; \ 0, m_{ii} \Big) \ \chi^2 \left(\widehat{\sigma}^2 (n-p-r_i^2); \ n-p-1 \right).

Denoting v=nâˆ’pv = n-p, the Jacobian of the transformation is âˆ£ÏƒÌ‚miirimiiâˆ’2ÏƒÌ‚2ri2ÏƒÌ‚vâˆ’2ÏƒÌ‚ri2âˆ£=2ÏƒÌ‚2vmii. \begin{equation} \begin{vmatrix} \widehat{\sigma} \sqrt{m_{ii}} & r_i \sqrt{m_{ii}} \\ -2 \widehat{\sigma}^2r_i & 2 \widehat{\sigma}v - 2\widehat{\sigma} ri^2 \end{vmatrix} = 2\widehat{\sigma}^2v \sqrt{m_{ii}} \end{equation}.

Hence, f(ri,ÏƒÌ‚)=2ÏƒÌ‚2vmiiğ’©(riÏƒÌ‚mii;0,mii)Ï‡2(ÏƒÌ‚2(vâˆ’ri2);vâˆ’1). f(r_i, \widehat{\sigma}) = 2\widehat{\sigma}^2v \sqrt{m_{ii}} \ \mathcal{N} \Big(r_i \widehat{\sigma} \sqrt{m_{ii}}; \ 0, m_{ii} \Big) \ \chi^2 \Big(\widehat{\sigma}^2 (v-r_i^2); \ v-1 \Big).

Finally, simplifying and integrating over ÏƒÌ‚\widehat{\sigma} yields f(ri)=v1âˆ’v/2(vâˆ’ri2)(vâˆ’3)/2Î“(v2)Î“(vâˆ’12)Ï€,âˆ£riâˆ£<v. f(r_i) = \frac{v^{1-v/2} (v-r_i^2)^{(v-3)/2} \Gamma \left(\frac{v}{2} \right)}{\Gamma \left(\frac{v-1}{2} \right) \sqrt{\pi}}, \quad \mid r_i \mid < \sqrt{v}.

Using $\tt Mathematica$ we find $$ F(r_i) = \frac{v^{1-\frac{v}{2}} \Gamma \left(\frac{v}{2} \right)}{\Gamma \left(\frac{v-1}{2} \right) \sqrt{\pi}} r_i \left(1 - \frac{r_i^2}{v} \right)^{\frac{3-v}{2}} \Big(v-r_i^2 \Big)^{\frac{v-3}{2}} \\ _2F_1 \left( \frac{1}{2}, \frac{3-v}{2}, \frac{3}{2}, \frac{r^2}{v} \right) + C, $$ where 2F1_2F_1 is the hypergeometric function. A visual inspection of F(x)F(x) indicates that C=12C = \frac{1}{2} and the calculation of p-values and confidence intervals is straightforward. We just need to find the 1âˆ’Î±/21-\alpha/2 percentile, multiplicate it by ÏƒÌ‚mii\widehat{\sigma}\sqrt{m_{ii}} and add eie_i.

The R function resid_ci takes the output of a lm class object and does all the work.

# Distribution function of r:
pr <- function(r, v) {
  if(abs(r) >= sqrt(v)) {
    return(0)
  }
  v^(1-v/2)*gamma(v/2)/(gamma((v-1)/2) * sqrt(pi))*
  r*(1-r^2/v)^((3-v)/2)*(v-r^2)^((v-3)/2)*
    Re(hypergeo::hypergeo(1/2, (3-v)/2, 3/2, r^2/v)) + 1/2
}
# Notice you need the 'hypergeo' package.

# Function to get and plot the confidence intervals:
resid_ci <- function(lm, confidence, plot = NULL) {
   alpha <- 1 - confidence
   hat_y <- modelo$fitted.values
   e <- modelo$residuals
   v <- modelo$df.residual
   hat_sigma2 <- sum(e^2) / v
   m <- 1 - lm.influence(modelo)$hat
   se <- sqrt(hat_sigma2 * m)
   r <- e / se
   # Bounds for the domain of r:
   u <- sqrt(v) - 0.01
   l <- -u
   critical_value <- uniroot(f = function(r, v, alpha) pr(r, v) - (1-alpha/2),
          v = v, alpha = alpha, lower = l, upper = u)$root
   CI <- sapply(c(-1, 1), FUN = function(x) e + x*critical_value * se)
   colnames(CI) <- c("lower limit", "upper limit")
   if(!is.null(plot)) {
      plot(hat_y[plot], e[plot], ylim = c(max(CI[plot, ]), min(CI[plot, ])), 
        ylab = "Residuals", xlab = "Fitted values")
      sapply(plot, FUN = function(x) segments(x0 = hat_y[x], x1 = hat_y[x], 
                                          y0 = CI[x, 1], y1 = CI[x, 2]))
      segments(x0 = min(hat_y[plot]), x1 = max(hat_y[plot]), y0 = 0, y1 = 0, lty = 2)
   }
   return(CI)
}

The plot argument can be used to plot a subset of residuals by providing its indexes.

set.seed(25022020)
# Set-up:
n <- 20
p <- 4
v <- n-p
X <- cbind(1, MASS::mvrnorm(n, mu = rep(0, p-1), Sigma = diag(p-1)))
beta <- c(1, 0.2, 0.5, 0.8)
sigma <- rchisq(1, 5)
# Simulation:
epsilon <- rnorm(n, 0, sigma)
y <- X %*% beta + epsilon
# Model:
modelo <- lm(y ~ 0 + X)
# Plotting the confidence intervals with alpha = .05:
resid_ci(modelo, confidence = .95, plot = 1:n)

##    lower limit upper limit
## 1   -19.464750   0.7951401
## 2   -17.696498   1.6501012
## 3    -5.550288  13.2235236
## 4   -15.831542   4.7842290
## 5    -6.212853  15.2809272
## 6   -10.152657  11.7342894
## 7   -14.961725   6.2331182
## 8    -5.813860  14.1868663
## 9   -16.738508   3.2498009
## 10  -13.733734   7.9669237
## 11   -8.529167  13.4177885
## 12  -10.779609   9.1548674
## 13  -12.121683   4.7811506
## 14   -6.199955  14.0267908
## 15    3.315743  23.4428353
## 16   -5.336643  15.7564900
## 17  -12.674718   8.8032118
## 18   -9.720376   9.6704875
## 19   -9.200522  12.9166644
## 20   -7.601659  13.9297983

And as we should expect in the long run under the homocedastic and normality assumptions, only one of the 2020 residuals deviated from the model.

Reference

Ellenberg, J. H. (1973). The Joint Distribution of the Standardized Least Squares Residuals from a General Linear Regression. Journal of the American Statistical Association, 68(344), 941â€“943. https://doi.org/10.1080/01621459.1973.10481450
